Clinical studies show sustained relief for up to three years.

schema.howPerformed: After numbing your knee with local anesthetic, a specialist uses live ultrasound imaging to guide a fine needle directly into the joint space. A smooth, gel-like substance (polyacrylamide hydrogel) is carefully injected. This special gel doesn't dissolve or wash away—it bonds with the soft lining inside your knee, creating a lasting cushion that protects worn cartilage. The whole procedure takes about 10 minutes
schema.preparation: Fast for 4 hours before (light fluids okay). Wear loose, comfortable trousers. Stop blood-thinning supplements one week prior if safe. Bring someone to drive you home. Your knee will be cleaned and draped in a sterile field. Relax—many patients say it's far less uncomfortable than they expected
schema.followup: Rest your knee for 48 hours—no weight training, running, or prolonged standing. Gentle walking around the house is fine. Use ice packs and prescribed pain relief. The gel needs 4-12 weeks to fully integrate and start cushioning effectively. Attend your week 12 follow-up for assessment. Gradually resume activities as pain allows, guided by physiotherapy
schema.outcome: Over 4-12 weeks, knee pain steadily decreases. The grinding, catching sensation improves. You can walk, climb stairs, and enjoy activities that hurt before. The cushioning effect lasts up to 3 years—far longer than steroid or hyaluronic acid injections. Many patients delay or avoid knee replacement surgery entirely. Your quality of life improves significantly
schema.medicationRequired: Local anesthetic injection to numb the knee. Optional oral sedative for anxious patients
schema.treatmentFrequency: Single injection provides relief for up to 3 years. Some patients choose a repeat injection after 2-3 years if symptoms gradually return. No need for frequent repeat visits like other knee injections
schema.adverseOutcome: Temporary knee swelling, stiffness, or warmth for 2-5 days (normal response to injection). Small bruise at injection site. Very rarely, infection (we use strict sterile technique) or allergic reaction to the gel

seriousAdverseOutcome.name: Joint infection (septic arthritis)
seriousAdverseOutcome.probability: Extremely rare (less than 0.1%) with proper sterile technique. We use single-use equipment and pharmaceutical-grade products in a clinical setting
